docs.lead_paragraph: MALINOW--M. Rene, MD, who as a basic and clinical scientist was among the first who showed the importance of exercise, cholesterol and homocysteine in heart disease, findings which are now in medical textbooks and led to changes in people's behavior and health, died April 20 at his home in Portland, OR. He was 90. Dr. Malinow, who was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, got his medical degree from Buenos Aires Medical School at the age of 23. He completed a fellowship in cardiology at the Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago, IL. He practiced medicine at the Hospital Ramos Mejia in Buenos Aires until 1963, when he moved to Portland, OR to work at the Oregon National Primate Research Center, where he remained as chief of cardiovascular diseases for 40 years. Dr. Malinow published more than 300 studies, which received over 14,000 citations and delivered hundreds of invited lectures in over 20 countries. He was recipient of the 1996 Achievement Award from the American College for the Advancement in Medicine. He was a former fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and former member of the New York Academy of Sciences. Dr. Malinow was a mentor to hundreds of physicians and scientists in three continents. He will be remembered not only for his distinguished contribution to science but as a devoted husband and father as well. In addition to his wife of 57 years, Tita Malinow of Portland, OR, Dr. Malinow is survived by two sons, Roberto from San Diego, CA and Sebastian from Portland, OR; one daughter, Ana Malinow Rajkovic from Pittsburgh, PA; and six grandchildren, Max and Chester Malinow; Andrei, Adi and Gabriel Rajkovic; and Rose Aria Malinow. The family has requested that flowers not be sent and that expressions of sympathy be directed to The Alzheimer's Association Oregon Chapter and Chamber Music Northwest.

docs.lead_paragraph: Acupuncture involves the use of fine needles inserted at specific points on the body, which is believed by practitioners to unblock the flow of energy.

headline.seo: The Ancient Art of Acupuncture, in a Western Context
headline.main: Ancient Chinese Art, in a Western Context
headline.print_headline: A Chinese Art, In the Context Of the West

docs.lead_paragraph: Acupuncture is a traditional Chinese medicine that has been in use for thousands of years. At your first evaluation, a practitioner will examine your tongue for clues like cracks and discolorations, take your pulse and ask numerous questions to determine what might be causing your symptoms.

headline.main: A Chinese Art, In the Context Of the West
